stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware Command and Control IP Address
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 10 June 2015, a malware implant installed on a U.S. Government network called back to a Pakistan-registered IP address 115.186.173.224. The information included which port was available for callback along with some system information.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This IP address was observed in command and control traffic.
The malware observed facilitates peer-to-peer (P2P) communications between implants and provides remote access capabilities to the attackers. According to the report, the attackers can likely task an implant to use the remote access capabilities of another implant. For example, the implant could probably use one implant to relay a 'delete file' command to another implant.
While full details of this implant are not available at this time, the malware configuration information is typically stored in a file named "mssscardprv.ax". This file is typically located in "C:\WINDOWS\system32" and includes a list of peer IP addresses and TCP ports. The implant runs two main threads; one to accept incoming connections and another to initiate connections to other peers. Each client in the peer-to-peer malware connection is likely a compromised end-point or used as part of the attacker's infrastructure.
It is unknown which infection vectors were used to deploy the implant to these particular victims, although the implants are typically deployed with a worm capable of brute force authentication attacks to propagate through networks via Windows server message block (SMB) shares. Other infection vectors and malware could also be used to deploy the implant.
